headline.main: U.S. Considers Food Labels With Whole-Package Data

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration is considering whether to require food companies to list nutrition information in its entirety, rather than by serving size, on packaged-food labels (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it was considering whether to require food companies to list nutrition information in its entirety, rather than by serving size, on packaged-food labels. Currently, if a package contains more than one serving, consumers must multiply nutrition data by the number of servings to determine total calories, fat and carbohydrates. Some consumer groups and nutritionists have argued that such food labels are misleading and could cause consumers to take in more calories, sodium and fat than they realize. Now, it seems, the F.D.A. may agree.

headline.main: At a Harvard Cafe, Health for Lunch

docs.abstract: Marian Burros comments on healthful meals served at Sebastian's Cafe at Harvard School of Public Health in Boston (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IF you make healthful food look good and taste good, can you get people to eat more of it? At Sebastian's Cafe at the Harvard School of Public Health in Boston, the answer is a resounding yes. Over the last five years, sales of hamburgers have dropped from 50 a day to fewer than 20. Sales of French fries have not changed, but the fries have. They are cooked in oil free of trans fatty acids. Regular pizzas continue to outsell whole wheat pizzas by a wide margin, but there are enough customers to sell five whole wheat pizzas every day.

headline.main: The Smoke and Mirrors Of Food Labeling

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration says it will not tighten rules on packaged food labeling despite complaints from nutritionists and consumer activists that food companies routinely exploit laws to make products appear healthier and less fattening; much of problem stems from inconsistent and unrealistic definition of serving size; health advocates want new labeling standards based on entire package rather than individual serving; FDA maintains that American eating habits have not changed sufficiently enough to warrant new labeling rules; chart; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Food companies -- including some that have pledged to act in the face of rising obesity rates -- routinely exploit labeling laws that allow them to make their products seem less fattening than they really are, according to nutritionists and consumer groups. But the Food and Drug Administration, which establishes the rules for the food industry, said that it was not planning any action on packaged food labeling and, last month, was considering a new program for displaying nutritional information in restaurants, as well.
